ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had one day of asynchronous learning every week, and a thirty minute private session with a Chinese tutor every week.
We had a discussion day that was done online asynchronously.  We also went to a tutor every week for 30 minutes.
Virtual seminar with breakout rooms
None
We also did zoom seminar/discussions for chapter topics and drilled exercises too.
Asynchronous thursdays with a discussion post and additional tutorial with a tutor

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We learned lots of new words, phrases, and grammar points to help make our Mandarin more authentic.
My Chinese improved a lot in all fronts: speaking, reading, and writing. The teachers were enthusiastic and engaging.
Improved my Chinese greatly, learned vital phrases and character writing.
Learned pinyin and writing characters as well as expanding vocab. It was also a nice introduction to Chinese culture/way of life
I learned how to speak Chinese properly, read and write more vocabulary, and interesting facts about Chinese culture and history.
I was able to expand on my Chinese reading and writing skills.
I learned a LOT of Chinese. Mostly grammar structure and how to read and write

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength was the use of fun verbal drills and interesting discussions that tested our ability to express our ideas in Mandarin.

Strengths are Professor Liu, who brings so much energy every day, and the course is pretty well organized. However, the course work is very taxing, with class section every day and expected work to be almost an hour. At times, the work is very repetitive. At times, the calendar dates are hard to navigate and a better system would make things easier.

Liu laoshi is amazing! Very kind and patient and truly cares about the learning and success of each student. Most people in this level have some experience with pinyin and writing characters since they oftentimes have attended Chinese school, so the basics of pinyin and character writing are not taught; however, if you need extra help, there are a LOT of resources available.
The course is very thorough and helped improve my Chinese greatly. It's at a steady pace so I never felt too overwhelmed but I was also learning a lot.
The course was a bit hard in the beginning as I didn't know how to read or write Chinese at the beginning. However, I felt I was eventually able to catch up and it became easier over time.
I like how it was taught. The beginning was like being thrown in the deep end to be taught how to swim, but after the first midterm it was better.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having one day of asynchronous learning lessened the burden of the language class, while still allowing us to practice our Mandarin through online discussions.
Weekly tutoring sessions with a teaching fellow were very beneficial.
The breakout room discussions were nice. The zoom lectures also worked well, but when drilling exercises, the lag was distractingly slow.
The teacher made the virtual live lectures engaging. We occasionally had enjoyable class-wide discussions where we would use Chinese to talk about our viewpoints and ideas.
My prof did a really good job with transitioning to online learning. I liked being able to see her hype grammar structures out and see the words characters on her presentation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. If you enjoy learning Chinese and already have a pretty strong background in listening/understanding Chinese, then this course is not that difficult but very informative.

I'd recommend this course to a student who has Chinese background and is looking for a nice medium that will build on skills they already have from whatever introductions to Chinese they have experienced. While it moves relatively fast, Professor Liu is excellent at communicating with her students, and also creates an environment with lots of participation.
Yes, all the Chinese teachers at Yale are very kind and love to teach, and they make the class very enjoyable.

Yes!! I highly recommend it!! I came into this class knowing no pinyin nor characters, but did have a solid speaking/listening/comprehension background, so the first few weeks as well as the first test were pretty rough. However, once I learned the basics, everything clicked into place. Liu laoshi is extremely accommodating and wants you to succeed. The tutorial sessions were also really helpful in reviewing chapter exercises and could be customized to fit your needs.
Yes, even though it has only been one semester, my Chinese has already improved so much. I'm glad to have learned so much already, and I'm looking forward to 142!
I think this course is helpful if you really want to learn Chinese. However, be prepared to put in a lot of work.
Yes. Although challenging, I learned a lot.
